node.text:
James recently tasted the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum, which impressed him so much he said to Lucie Pereyre de Nonacourt, who represents the fourth generation at Champagne Laurent-Perrier, and Edouard Cossy, the company's global director: "The aromas were amazing. Honestly, I can't think of a more beautiful Champagne with the aromas... that sort of brioche and tarte au limon." 

Lucie tells the story of how her grandfather founded the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée. When he became director of the house, he realized he had to have a prestige cuvée. He based the creation of his cuvée on a unique blend, which would take the champagne further in terms of quality and thus achieve his goal of recreating the perfect year – "one that nature cannot provide." 

Check out their conversation now to learn more about the Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum and when to expect its release.

node.text:
American Pinot Noir producer Adam Lee wears many hats: he was a co-founder of Siduri Wines (and remains a consultant and winemaker), founded the Clarice Wine Company, and co-founded Beau Marchais Wine with famed vintner Philippe Cambie. 

In this chat with JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt, Adam talks about his approach in making pinot through whole-cluster fermentation and why he varied whole-cluster percentages for the 2017-19 vintages. Claire also asks Adam for his thoughts on the uncertainty of the final product and whether whole-cluster fermentation can affect a wine negatively, to which Adam responds: "Yes, there is a risk you could have unripe stems ... [but] one of the things I have found on stem ripeness is it has to do with the length of hang time and does not correlate with sugar maturity." 

Check out the rest of their conversation for more of Adam's thoughts on pinots and their future on the West Coast.

#California #CalifornianWine #ClariceWineCompany @claricewinecompany #BeauMarchaisWine @beaumarchaiswines #pinotnoir #westcoastwines #wine #winemaker #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

The sixth and last session of the Grand Tastings for Great Wines of the World 2021: Autumn Edition. Thank you to everybody who came to experience these amazing wines and thank you to the wine producers as well. See you soon at James Suckling Wine Central for an upcoming Masterclass, or even if you are stopping by just for great food and wine.

For more information on the upcoming Masterclasses please visit JamesSuckling.com

node.text:
Great Wines of the World Grand Masterclass began today featuring 177 wines from 88 wineries. Wine trade and keen consumers were happy to compare vintages, regions, countries as well as try lots of new releases. 

James gave some advice on tasting strategies for the Masterclass and wines and vintages not to miss.

node.text:
James sits down with Michel Friou and Manuel Louzada, the winemaker and managing director, respectively, at Viña Almaviva in Chile to discuss the 2019 Epu, which James calls a "beautiful second wine." 

"One question is, how did you finally decide to do a second wine and why?" James asks Manuel. "It's a very delicious wine." 

"After 25 years we definitely believed that we already have brand recognition, brand awareness, that Almaviva was already recognized because of the quality of the wine and because of its reputation," Manuel says. "From a business standpoint, the decision was, 'Let's focus on Almaviva ... and then afterward we started again in 2006 [with Epu] ... in basically two markets: Chile and Brazil.'" 

They also talk about the decision to sell Epu through La Place de Bordeaux, where negociants will redistribute it throughout the world. Check out the video now for the full conversation. 

#Chile #ChileanWine #MaipoValley #MaipoValleyWine #Almaviva #AlmavivaWinery #AlmavivaWine @almavivawinery  #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt sits down with Domaine Serene Winemaker Michael Fay to ask about the proportion of pinot noir versus chardonnay grapes used at the winery, as well as its plans for making more chardonnay. 

"We're definitely bullish on chardonnay," Michael says. "We really believe in three things for chardonnay that really make this style of chardonnay that we want. We're really only interested in planting chardonnay in high elevations, on Jory soils ... and using Dijon clones, which are early-ripening clones of chardonnay." 

Watch their video interview for free now at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Florent Genty, commercial director of Chateau Nenin, presents Chateau Nenin Pomerol 2018. This wine will be shown at the Grand Tasting Sessions held at Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong from Sept. 2-3. 

Chateau Nenin is a large estate by Pomerol standards, with 32 hectares of vineyards in production. The owners of this estate, the Delons who also own the famous second growth of Leoville Las Cases, are starting to use this to their advantage, making rigorous selections at harvest time and favoring low-yielding, older vines. The fine tannins in these silky Right Bank wines make them ethereal — try them for yourself and you’ll soon understand why.

node.text:
James sits down with Napa Valley winemaker Andy Erickson to talk about how the current Napa harvest is going and how it compares with previous years. They also taste the 2018 Favia wines and 2019 Leviathan California. 

James says of the Leviathan, "It's sort of fruit-forward ... but at the same time remains really agile and fresh," and asks Andy the secret behind it. 

"I just wanted a wine that you could go out to a steakhouse and if I saw it on the menu, I would want it," Andy says. "This is the wine I like to drink. It's rich, it's flavorful, it's very fresh, and it's got the structure of a Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon and sort of that character, but it's made from different varieties – it's cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc, merlot, syrah and now even a little petite syrah."

node.text:
In this Tasting Interview, associate editor Claire Nesbitt and winemaker Veronique Boss-Drouhin of Domaine Drouhin consider the 2019 vintage - the terroir, soils and climate in Willamette, but also the 2020 vintage and how smoke taint could be an issue. Followed by this was their discussion on the unique spicy nature and fine-grained tannins of the Oregon pinot, and the potential for chardonnay in the region.

node.text:
Associate Editor Claire Nesbitt speaks with Tom Gerrie, winegrower and second-generation owner of Cristom Vineyards in Willamette Valley, Oregon, on how the state's pinot noirs compare with those from Sonoma County, California. Tom describes Oregon's fruit as "relatively bright. it's relatively high-toned, relatively red-fruited for the most part. I do think we have some differences based on soil... Our [deep] volcanic soils are extremely bright and red-fruited. Very, very high tone and very floral." Check out the video to hear Tom's thoughts on why Oregon chardonnays lag pinot noirs in popularity, and on his hopes for riesling.

node.text:
Is the 2018 vintage in Spain the new 1964? Find out in James' conversation with Telmo Rodriguez, the founder and winemaker at his namesake Telmo Rodriguez winery. "I think '18 is an amazing vintage for Rioja," Telmo says. "I think in 2018 you will see amazing, delicate, fresh and beautiful tannins in Rioja in general."

node.text:
What changes are on the horizon for Chianti Classicos? James talks with Giovanni Manetti, the owner of Fontodi Winery and president of the Chianti Classico Consortium, to find out how Gran Seleziones are doing in the marketplace. Giovanni takes James through sales of Gran Seleziones, the new subregion classification being applied to Gran Seleziones, and changes in the blend – specifically the minimum amount of sangiovese allowed, among other changes. He also breaks down whether winemakers can buy grapes for Gran Selezione and whether the consortium will still have a tasting panel.

node.text:
Coming in at #6 on our list of Top 100 Wines of France in 2020 was the Chateau d’Yquem Sauternes 2017. 

Our tasters said this bottle delivers “thrilling purity and intensity,” with the nose offering “aromas of fresh and dried apricot and peach pastry, as well as freshly baked creme brulee, candied and fresh orange and kumquat.” 

The 2017 Yquem is a very powerful wine from a very rich and exceptional vintage, and the acidity has a big hand in balancing the richness. Great quality and one of the best since the legendary 2001. Drink or hold. 

For more details on our Top 100 Wines of France in 2020, and to see more of our Top 100 reports, please click on the link in the bio or visit JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
James recently tasted the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum, which impressed him so much he said to Lucie Pereyre de Nonacourt, who represents the fourth generation at Champagne Laurent-Perrier, and Edouard Cossy, the company's global director: "The aromas were amazing. Honestly, I can't think of a more beautiful Champagne with the aromas... that sort of brioche and tarte au limon." 

Lucie tells the story of how her grandfather founded the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée. When he became director of the house, he realized he had to have a prestige cuvée. He based the creation of his cuvée on a unique blend, which would take the champagne further in terms of quality and thus achieve his goal of recreating the perfect year – "one that nature cannot provide." 

Check out their conversation now to learn more about the Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum and when to expect its release. 

#France #FrenchWine #Champagne #ChampagneWine #ChampagneLaurentPerrier #LaurentPerrierChampagne @champagnelaurentperrier #GrandSiecle #GrandCuvee #magnum #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Chile’s iconic winery, Seña, celebrated its 25th Anniversary in Hong Kong and Shanghai on Saturday night with multi-course dinners simultaneously held in both cities and a video link with owner Eduardo Chadwick and participants. Guests enjoyed a vertical of Seña's wines starting with the 1996, followed by the 2009, 2015, 2017 and the 2019 – the 25th anniversary vintage. The star was the 2015 (100 points) but James admitted that the 2017 (99 points) was a very close second. The 2019 is a beautiful wine as well (98 points). Wine trade members at both events reveled in the quality of the wines and the story behind Seña, which is a single estate in the Aconcagua Valley north of Santiago. It is all biodynamically farmed. Recent vintages of Seña are made of mostly cabernet sauvignon with malbec and carmenere as well as a touch of petit verdot.

node.text:
A Masterclass of a selection of 2011 wines from St. Emilion today during our Great Wines of World Edition 3 program showed some pretty development of fruit, with varied evolution 10 years on. The hard tannins of their youth are melting away. JamesSuckling.com’s Claire Nesbitt and Kevin Davy were happy with the quality of the wines along with the 20 or so participants. Prices remain low for this more classic vintage, following on from the better known 2009 and 2010: with careful selection, 2011 offers some excellent value wines that are drinking well now.

node.text:
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: THE WINE THAT SCORED 100 POINTS IN THE LATEST WEEKLY TASTING REPORT 

Senior Editor Stuart Pigott found a gem in the 2020 vintage in a recent tasting with Felix Keller of Weingut Keller in Germany: the Keller Riesling Rheinhessen Brünnenhäuschen Abts E GG 2020, which has a structure and depth that’s rare in this vintage. The peach, melon and mint nose is already very deep and delicate, while a vibrant grapefruit character and great minerality shows on the palate with a long finish. 

Find out about all the wines that impressed in our latest Weekly Tasting Report at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
The most important grape variety for Sicilian red wines is the indigenous nero d’avola, which become a fashion wine around the last turn of the century. That popularity is easy to understand when you taste a good example brimming with black fruit and spice aroma, mouth-filling and richly textured. That’s the way the excellent red wines from the Gulfi winery in Catania tasted. We were a little surprised when they sent us their 2014 vintage single-vineyard wines, but the freshness of these seven-year-olds was seriously impressive.

An important specialty of Sicily is the Zibbibo grape (shown here), also known as Muscat of Alexandria, which makes everything from aromatic and refreshing dry whites to the luscious Passito di Pantelleria dessert wines.

Donnafugata’s Ben Ryé 2019 is the most exciting Passito from the volcanic island of Pantelleria we have tasted to date. It has a cornucopia of dried fruit aromas and a wonderful balance of exquisite sweetness and energetic freshness.

For more insights on Sicilian wines, read Senior Editor Stuart Pigott’s report for free only at JamesSuckling.com. It comes with more than 350 tasting notes!

node.text:
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: A PINOT TASTING WITH WINEMAKER ADAM LEE 

Over a recent tasting of his new California pinot noir projects with JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt, Adam Lee (pictured) of Clarice and Beau Marchais shared details on his approach to whole-bunch pressing, the importance of the ripening process and climatic influences, as well as the Chateauneuf grenache-inspired winemaking for Beau Marchais, with unusually long hang time and extended skin maceration producing a more powerful style of pinot noir. 

Listen to this podcast for free now at JamesSuckling.com.

#WinePodcast #PodcastersofInstagram #California #CalifornianWine #westcoastwine #pinotnoir #SiduriWines #ClariceWineCompany #BeauMarchaisWines @claricewinecompany @beaumarchaiswines #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Few wineries have done as much as Provence winery Domaines Ott to raise the reputation of rosé as a wine of class and pedigree. Indeed, it is often argued that Cotes de Provence owes its success as a source of the world's top rosés to Marcel Ott, the founder of Domaines Ott, who moved to the region in 1896. These are full-bodied, fresh and sometimes mineral rosés that mark this type of wine as worthy of serious contemplation. Since 2004 the winery has been two-thirds owned by the Rouzaud family of Louis Roederer. 

Here, Jean-Francois Ott, co-owner and winemaker of Domaines Ott, presents Château de Selle 2020. 

This wine is being shown at the JamesSuckling.com Great Wines of the World Autumn Edition 2021 being held in Hong Kong from Sept. 2 to Sept. 25. You can find more details on the schedule and Masterclasses at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
JUST IN: THE WINE WORLD’S INSTAGRAM EDGE: MOST-FOLLOWED ACCOUNTS

How does everyone in the Wine World stack up on Instagram? We did a deep dive to find out who has the most-followed accounts. Plenty of Champagne houses, some big-name media, and James, too:

1)	Moet & Chandon: 705,000 Instagram followers
2)	Dom Perignon: 657,000
3)	Luc Belaire 562,000
4)	Wine Spectator: 541,000
5)	Wine Enthusiast: 481,000
6)	Wine Folly: 378,000
7)	Rare Wine: 292,000
8)	James Suckling: 287,000
9)	Veuve Clicquot: 273,000
10)	Robert Parker Wine Advocate: 249,000
11)	Decanter: 229,000
12)	Armand de Brignac: 215,000
13)	Winery Lovers: 208,000
14)	Krug Champagne: 201,000
15)	Wine Teller: 183,000

For the complete story from Managing Editor Vince Morkri, click on the bio to take you to the free article on JamesSuckling.com.
